DIV2.HEAD: Here bigynnyth the lyfe of Marye Magdaleyn.
DIV2.P:
MAry Magdaleyn was surnamed of Magdalon, the castell, and she was born of the kynred, that were descendid of ryal kynne, and hir fadir highte Syrus, and hir modir *highte Eucharie. And she aand Lazar, hir brothir, and Martha, hir sustre, sustre eher, als sustir hilden that castel, that is two myle fro Genazereth, and Bethanye, Bethanye] h aus etwas anderem that is nyghe to Ierusa∣lem, and a gret partye of Ierusalem. And thei devided bthese thynges by-twene hem in suche wyse, that Marie had Magdalon, wher-of she was surnamed, and Lazar *had partye of Ierusalem, and Martha
*had Bethanye. And thanne *Mary Magdaleyen was yoven al to the delycys of the body, and *hir brother Lazar entendid most to knyg[ht]hode, and Martha, that was wyse *and gouerned the partye cof hir brothir and of hir sustre, suster (so eher, als sustir) auf Rasur *she mynestrid to knyghtes and to seruauntes and to pore men her necessytees. And thei solde al these thynges after the ascensyoun of oure lorde and brought *al the monye ther-of to the apostellys feete. And *Mary Magdaleyn abundyd *gretly in rychesse, and, for that delite *she dis felawe to abundaunce of *other thinges, *and in as moche, as she shyned more in ebewte and richesse, so moche the more she had hir bodi sogette to delices, and therfore she loste hir propur name and was of custome callid the synful womman. And, whanne foure lorde preched ghir in erthe, she was enspired with hgrace and wente to the hous of Symon, the lepre, iwhanne oure lorde dyned there. But she durste not appere among the ryghtwys men, for she was synful; but she kcome to the feete of oure lorde, and there she wysshe hem with hir teeris and wypid hem with hir heer and anoynted hem with precyous oytmentis. For the dwellers of that londe vsyd lbathis and oyne∣mentys for the right gret heete of mthat londe. And, for that Sy∣monde thought in him-self, that, if noure lorde were a *verrey averrey Hs. pro∣phete, he wolde onot haue suffrid, a synful womman sholde haue touched him, *and there-fore oure lorde vndirtoke him of pverrey pride and for-yaffe the womman al hir synnes. And this [is] Mary
Magdaleyn, to whiche oure lorde yaff so *many gret yiftes and shewed so grete tokenes of loue, qthat he delyuered hir of feendes, and he sette hir al afire in his loue and made hir right famulier with him: he rwolde, she were his hostesse and his procuresse; he wolde, that she were with him in his viage; he excused hir alweie swetely. He excused hir ageyns the sphariseis, that seide, she was not clene, and ageyns hir sustur, that seide, that she was idil, and ageyns Iudas, that seide, she was a wastour *of goodis; and, whanne he sawe hir wepe, he myght not kepe his teeris. And for hir loue he reised *Lazar *fro deth to lyf, whiche had leyn foure daies ded, and he heelid hir sustir of the blody flixe, that had tholden hir vij. yere. And *also by the meritis of hir he made uMarcel, the chaumberer vof Martha, to be worthi to seie these swete wordis: 'Blessid be the wombe, that bare the, *and the brestis, that yafe the souke.' wBut Ambrose seithe, that it was Martha, *that seide these wordis, and xthese wordes were here chaumberers. This is *Mary, that wisshe the feete of oure lorde and wiped hem with hir heere hir her heere Hs. and anoyntid hem with *precyous oynementis and dide solempne penaunce in tyme of grace and ywas the furste, that chas the beste parte, that satte at the feete of oure lorde and hurde his wordis; *this is she, that anoynted zhis heed, that at the the auf Rasur passioun was besides the crosse, that made redi the oynementis and wolde anoynte his body and parte[d] not fro the sepulcre, to whom *Ihesu
Criste appered first, whanne he aroos *from deth to lyff, and she awas bfelawe to the appostulis. Thanne after the ascencyoun of oure lorde in the cxuij. yere of his passyoun, after that the Iewes had slayne Stephen and had dryven oute the tothir disciplis of dthat cuntre *and ethei fwere disparbled abrode amonge the gentiles and sowden the worde of god: than was seynt gMaximian amonge the appostulys, oon of the LXXij. disciplis of oure lorde, to whom Mary Magdaleyn had be recommaundid of blessyd *seynt Petre. And than, whan the disciplis were partid, seynte hMaxymyan, Mary Magdaleyn, Lazar, hir brother, and Martha, hir sustir, and iMarcel, the chamberer of Martha, and seynte kCenodyn, that was bore blynde, but oure lorde lyaffe him sight, alle these to-gidre and many othir crysten *were take of the mysbelevers and putte in a shippe shippe] hi aus ly? and sette in the see with-oute mgouernaunce *to that ende, that thei sholde alle be drowned, but bi the wil of god thei come to Marcell. And there thei fonde non, that wolde resceyve hem in-to her hous, but than thei dwellid in a porche, that was before a tempul of the pepul of that cuntre. And, whan the blyssid Mary Magdaleyn sawe the puple nassemble to that tempul forto do sacrifice to the ydollis, she aroos hir up opesibully with a glade visage and a dis∣crete tunge *and wel spekyng and pbigan to preche of *Ihesu Crist and to with-drawe the puple fro worsheppyng of ydollis. And than
alle hadden *grete merveyle of the bewte and of the resoun, *that was in hir, and of hir faire spekynge. And it was no wonder, though the mouthe, that so qdebonairely and so goodely kyssid the feete of oure rlorde, were more senspired with the worde of god, than other. And after that tit bifel, that the prynce of the provynce did sacrifyce to the ydollys, ubothe he and his wyfe, to haue a chi[l]de. And *Mary Magdaleyn prechid of *Ihesu Crist to vhem and wre∣provid his sacryfice. And xwith-inne a while after *Mary Magda∣leyn apperid to the lady in a vysioun avysioun Hs. seyng: 'How is it, sithe ythou hast so grete plente of richesse, that thow *darst leeve the *pore zservauntis of oure lorde deie for hungre and for *thurst and for colde?' And she was aferde to shewe this visyoun to hir lorde. And the seconde nyght she apperid to hir *ayeyn and seide to hir the same aand manasid hir *gretly, but if she wolde stere hir hus∣band for to brefresshe the pore cservauntes of oure lorde, dshe sholde repente hir; but yit ewolde she not seie it to hir housbonde. And than fthe thridde nyght she apperid to hem bothe, *as thei were in bedde to-gedris, and seide with an angry visage: 'Slepist thou, tyraunt? gremembre the of thi fader, hthe fende, with thi wyf, the serpent, that list not to telle the my wordis. Rest thow *now, enemy of the crosse, that hast the glotenye of the wombe ful, and thow suffrist to perisshe the seyntis of god? iThow liste in thi paleis wrappid with clothis of silke, and thow seest hem with-oute hous
*al discomfortid and takest non hede. Thow shalte not escape so *lightly, thow feloun, ne thow shalte not skape with-oute punshinge, pershinge Hs. that thow haste abide so long.' And, whan she had thus seide, she partid thens, and the ladi awooke and sighid, and khir housbonde also for that same cause, and tremblid, and thanne she seide: 'Sire, haue ye seyne the dreme, that I sawe?' 'I haue seyn it,' he seide, 'and haue *grete merveile and am *sore afferde.' And than his wyff seide to him: 'It is more profitable *to vs to obeie hir, than for to renne in the wreche of hir god, that she prechith of.' For whiche cause thei receyvid hem in-to hir hous and mynestryd to hem her necessites. In a ltyme, as Mary Magdaleyn prechid mto the forseide prynce, than seide the prynce to hir: 'Wenest thou, that thou myghtist diffende the lawe, that thou prechist?' And she seide: 'Syker, I am redy to diffende it, as nshe, that is confermyd euery daye bi myraclis and by the predicacioun of ooure maister, *seynt Petre, that psittith in the see of Rome.' To whom the prynce seide: 'I qand my wiff ben redi to obeie the in alle thyngis, if thou wilte be thi prayer gete vs a sone of *thi god, that thou prechist of.' And than *Mary Magdaleyn seide: 'For that it shal not abide.' And than the blessid rMagdaleyn prayed to oure lorde for hem, that he wolde of his mercy graunte hem a childe, and oure [lorde] harde hir prayer, and that lady conceyvid. And than the housbonde wolde go to *seynt Petre for to prove, whethir the verite merite Hs. were suche sof
*Ihesu Crist, as *Mary Magdeleyn prechid. And than his wif seide to him: 'Sire, wene ye to go with-oute me? tNay, in no wyse; for, whan ye go, I wol go and come ayen, *if god wole, whan ye come.' To whom hir housbonde seide: 'Wif, it it über der Zeile von derselben Hand wil not be; for ye be with childe , and the pereiles of the see ben with-oute nombre, and ye myghte lightly perysshe: ye shule abide at home and take hede of oure possessyons.' And uthe ladi strof, *as a woman, and *wolde not chaunge hir wommanli maners and fil doun *on hir knees to∣fore his fete wepyng, and at the laste he grauntid hir hir request. And than Mary *Magdeleyn marked hem on her shulders with the crosse, for that the vwicked enemy sholde not lette hem of her weie. And so thei chargide a shippe with grete abundaunce of of goode of alle Hs. alle thingis, that was necessarie to hem, and lefte alle her othir thingis in the kepynge of Mary Magdaleyn and wente her weie. And, whan thei had wseyled the cours of a daie and a nyght, the see bigan to swelle and the wynde to xencrese, so that alle ywere ful sore a-ferde, and nameli the ladi, that was with childe and was febul zand ful of angwisshe of so grete wawes and trobul of the see; aand for angwisshe the ladi bigan to traveile sodenli, and bi-twene the grete turmente of hir travaile and the strengthe of the tyme she brought forthe a sone, and *the ladi deide. And, whan the childe was borne, it bcriede for to haue had the brest of his modir and made a pitous noyse. cAllas, in what sorowe the childe was made sleere of his
modir, and he moste nedys deie, for ther was noght, that myght norysshe him! *Allas, what shal *this pylgryme do, dthat sawgh his wif dede and his childe brayinge with wepyng voyce sekynge the brestis of his modir? *The pilgryme wepte epitously and seide: 'Allas I wrecche, what shal fI doo? I desyred to haue had a sone, and now haue I lost bothe the modir gand the sone.' And the ship∣men cried *on the tother syde and seide: 'Caste we this *dede bodi in-to the see, hleste we perisshe ialle; for, as longe as it is with us, this ktempest wil lneuere cese.' And, whanne the shipmen had take the bodi forto haue caste it in-to the see, the pylgryme seide: 'Suffrith *a while, suffrith, and, though ye wil not spare me ne mmy wyf, yet spare at the leste this litul babe, that wepith *and cryeth. Abideth a while *forto witte, [if] paraventure the womman be in a swoune with woo *and peyne and may, *and god wole, nawake ayen.' And than an hille apperid not ferre fro the shippe, and, whanne *the housbonde sawgh it, him thought it more goodly to bere the body and the childe thider, than to ocaste it in-to the see forto be dewoured pin the see. And than he qdide rso moche bi prayers and bi yiftys, that sthei sette her shippe towarde that hille *and bere the bodi thider. And, whan thei *sawgh, that tthei myght noght digge the uerthe for hardenesse *of the roche, thei leide the bodi in the moste secrete place in the mounteyn and vcouered it with a mantell, and than *the fadir leide the childe at the brest of wthe modir and seide with *sore wepinge: 'Mary Magdaleyn, thou come to Marcelle to myn xyville aventure. Allas I wrecche, whi toke I this
iorney vpon me bi thi techinge? Hast thou required of *thi god, that my wif shulde conceyue yto perisshe *hir *and the childe? zThis is that, that I haue receyued be thi prayers. *I recommende hir now to the, to whom I haue commaundid alle myne *othir thingis, and I recommaunde *hir to thi god, that, if ahe be myghti, that he bhelpe the soule of the moder, and that be thi prayers he haue pite on the childe, that it perisshe not.' And than he couered *al the bodi *of the modir cand *of the childe with his mantel and wente *ayen to the shippe. And, whanne he was come to *seynt Petre, dhe come ayens him and sawe the token of the crosse vpon his shol∣dere, and he asked him, what he was, and whens he come. And he tolde him al the *manere bi ordre; *than seide *seynt Petre: 'Pees be with the! Thou arte welcome; efor thou hast levide goode coun∣seil. Be not sory *ne hevi, though that thi wif slepe and thi litil sone restith with hir; for oure lorde *Ihesu *Crist is *al-mighti to yeue flif, to whom he wole, and to take ayen, *whan him list, that he hath youen *the, and for to turne *al thi vepinge in-to ioie.' And than *seynt Petre ladde him in-to Ierusalem, and *there he shewid him alle the placis, where *Ihesu Crist had prechid, and the place where he suffrid *deth, and where he styed in-to heuene. And, whan he was wel taught of *seynt Petre in the feith and that two yere were passid, he *toke his leve of seynt Petre and went in-to a shippe for to returne in-to his cuntre. And, as thei seiled, thei come bi the ordinaunce of god bi-sidis that roche, where the bodi of his wif gand
*of his childe had ben putte. And than he hdide *so moche bi prayers and bi yiftys, that thei sette the shippe thider. And the childe had *alweie be kepte *in-to that tyme bi Mary Magdeleyn and wente often-tymes, *whan he couthe go, to the see side and, as ithe childe, pleied with the litul stones, *that he fonde vpon the ryvage. And, whan kthei come thider, thei fonde the childe pleyinge vpon the see side, as it was wonte to doo, and than he merveiled lgretli, what it myght be, and mcome thider. And, whan the childe sawgh nhem, whiche that had neuere seyn non suche thynge *bifore, he was aferde and fledde preuely to the brestis of his moder and hid him vnder the mantelle. And than the pylgryme wente for to se more clerly *this thinge *and come and sawgh the childe oright faire sowkynge the breste of his moder, and than he toke the childe and seide: 'O blessid Mary Magdaleyn, how I were blessid and alle thingis wel happid me, if my wif myght turne ayen to lif and come with me home in-to my cuntre! I wote vereli and bileve with-outen any drede, that thou, that hast youe *me the childe and hast fedde him two yere in this roche, myghtest *wel bi thi i in thi aus etwas anderem prayer restore the modir to hir firste heele.' And with thoo wordis the pmodir respired and seide, right as though she had a-wakyd fro an *harde slepe: 'Blessid Mary Magdeleyn, *how thou arte of grete merite and gloryous *in the sight of god; for in *alle qmy grete sorowe of my trauail of childe thou rwere to me a mydwife, and in alle my necessitees thou hast sbenegneli servid me.' And, whan the
pilgryme hurde this thinge, he merueyled him and seide: 'Lyvist thou, my *right dere wif?' To whom she seide: '*Yee, surly, I live and am right now come fro the pilgrymage, that ye come fro, and, right as the blessid Petre ladde yow *aboute Ierusalem and shewid yow alle the placis, where toure lorde suffrid udeth and was buried, and many othir placis, I was with yow, vand Mary Magdeleyn wwas mi mi über der Zeile von derselben Hand felawe and my ledere, and I sawgh *al the placis there and haue hem *wel in mynde;' and tolde alle the placis and the miraclis, that *hir husbonde had seen, and wente xneuere oute of the weie in non *article. And than the pilgryme receyuyd his wif and his childe and wente ful of ioie in-to the shippe, and with-inne a while after thei arryved at the porte of Marcellis and fonde the blessid Mary Magdeleyn prechinge with hir disciplis, and than thei knelid doun to hir and tolde hir al, that was bifalle hem, and re∣ceyved bapteme of seynt yMaxymien. And than thei distroied zalle the templis of the ydolles in the citee of Marcellis and made chirchis of *Ihesu Criste and chosen bi accorde the blessid Lazar for to be *there bisshop of that citee. And in the ende thei come be the wil of god to the citee aof Daies, and bi many miraclis thei brought the puple to the feith of bgod, and there was cMaxymien made bisshop. And in this mene tyme the blessid Mary Magdeleyn was so covetous of the dsouerayne loue of god, that [she] echase right
a sharpe *place in the deserte and *was in a place, that was or∣deyned *for hir bi the hondis of aungellis, *and there she dwellid xxx. wyntir fwith-oute knowliche of any creature. In whiche place there was gneuere cours of watir ne comforte of trees ne of herbes; *and it was done for this cause, that it sholde be *clerli shewid, that oure hlorde wolde ifeede hir kwith heuenli metis and not with ertheli metis. And euery day at leuery houre of the day she was lifte up man high with angellis and hurde the glorious songe of the hevenli nfelawshipe with bodeli eris; where-with she was euery day ofedde with these right swete metis, and than was she pborn with these aungellis to hir propur qplacis, so that she had rno nede of bodeli norshinge. *So it befil in a tyme, that a prest, that desired to live a solitarie liff, stoke a selle for him-self *evene xij. tbowshotis ufro hir place. And in a daie oure [lorde] opened the eyen of that prest, vthat he sawgh with his bodeli eyen, in whiche manere the aungellis discendid doun to the forseide place, where Mary *Magdeleyn dwellid, and how thei lifte hir up in-to the eyere, and than after bi the space of an houre thei brought hir ayen with dyvyne preysingis to the same place. And than the preest desired to knowe the trouthe of that merveilous visyon and recommaundid him-self bi his prayers to *oure lorde, his makere, and wwente xsureli with *grete deuocyoun to the forseide place. And, whan he neghed nygh bi a stones cast, his thies bigunne to ywexe so stiff, as though thei had ben fast ibounde, and *alle his zinwarde lymes bigan to atremble for drede.
And, whan he turned him to go, then his thies band his feete cwere redi to goo, but, whan he denforsid him to goo to that place, eal his bodi was in languor, and myght not meve him. And than fhe vndir∣stode with-outen any faile, that Das zweite t von that zum Teil weggeschnitten it was sume secrete heuenli thing *and a place, that non ertheli gman myght come too. And than he callid the name of hIhesu *Crist and cried: 'I coniour the bi the *vertu of oure lorde, that, if thou be man or any *other resonabul creature, that dwellist in that pitte, that thou answere me and telle me the trouthe e von trouthe weg∣geschnitten of the.' And, whan he had seide so three tymes, the blessid Mary Magdeleyn answerde *and seide: 'Come nere, e von nere weggeschnitten and thou shalte knowe the trouthe iof thi desire.' And than he come tremblyng khalfe weie to hir warde, and than she seide to him: 'Hast thou *not mynde lof the gospell, *that maketh mencyoun of that mright synful synful doppelt, das zweite Mal durchgestrichen woman, woman] der grössere Teil des n weggeschnitten that *wette and wisshe the feete of oure saviour with her teeris and wiped hem with hir heer and dis∣serued foryevenesse for in foryevenesse auf Rasur of her synnes?' nAnd than the preest seid: 'I remembre me *wel, and it is more, than xxx. wyntir, passid, that holi chirche levith and confessith, that it was was] das s weggeschnitten done.' And than she seide: 'It am I, that bi the space of xxx. wyntir ohaue ben here with-outen any worldeli felawship, and it was yistir-daie suffrid the to se, *and *right so euery daie I am lifte up bi the hondis of
aungellis aungellis] der zweite Strich des n weggeschnitten in-to the heire and haue disserved to here with my bodeli eris euery daie vij. tymes the right swete songe of the heuenli pfelawshipe. And, for it is shewid me, that I shal passe oute of this worlde, go to seynt qMaxymien and seie to him, that the nexte day aftir the resurreccyon of oure lorde in the *same tyme, that he is wonte to rgoo to mateyns, that he entre allone in-to his oratorie, and there he shal fynde me bi the smysterie and seruyce of aun∣gellis.' And *this preest hurde the voice of hir, right as the voice of an aungil, but he sawgh tno thyng. And than he wente uanon to seynt vMaximyen and tolde him al bi ordre, and than was wMaximyen fulfillid with gret ioie and yeldid grete thankyngys to oure xlorde, and in the day and the houre, ythat was seide him, he entred in-to his oratorie and sawgh the blessid Mary Magdeleyn, that was in the quere *in the felawshipe of aungellis, that had brought hir thider. And she was lifte up fro the erthe two cubitis of heighte and prayed and had hir hondis streight up zto oure lorde. And seynt aMaxymien dred[d]e for to goo to hir, and she turned hir towardis him and seide: 'Come hidir, *myn *owne fadir, and flee not thi doughter.' And than, whan he neyghid hir, as it is redde in the bokys of bMaxymien, *he sawgh, that bi continuel visyoun of aungellis ceuery daie the visage of this *holi lady [was so] shynynge, das it had ben a bright beeme of the sonne. And
than al the preestis were callid, and the blessid Mary Magdeleyne receyuyd the holy bodi of oure lorde of *Maxymyen, the bisshope, with grete eabundaunce of teeris, and after that she strecchid up hir bodi bifore the awtir, and fhir right holi soule passid to oure lorde. And aftir the passyng of hir holi spirite so grete a sauoure of swetnesse abode there, that it was felte bi the space of vij. daies gamonge hem. Maria Magdalena a Magdalo castro cognominata *clarissimis est orta natalibus, *utpote ex regia stirpe descendentibus: cuius pater Syrus, mater vero Eucharia nuncupata est. Haec acum fratre suo Lazaro et sorore sua Martha *Magdalum castrum, quod est secundo milliario a Genezareth, Bethaniam, quae est iuxta Ierusalem, et magnam Hierosolymorum partem possidebat. Qui tamen bomnia inter se taliter diviserunt, quod Maria Magdalum, a quo *et *Magda∣lena nuncupata est, Lazarus partem *urbis Ierusalem et Martha
Bethaniam possideret. Cum autem Magdalena deliciis corporis se totam exponeret et Lazarus plus militiae vacaret, Martha prudens partes csororis et fratris sui *strenue gubernabat *et militibus et famulis *suis ac pauperibus necessaria ministrabat. Omnia tamen haec post adscensionem domini vendiderunt et ad pedes apostolorum pretium posuerunt. Cum igitur Magdalena divitiis abundaret, quia rerum affluentiam voluptas comes dsequitur, quanto edivitiis et pul∣chritudine splenduit, tanto corpus suum voluptati substravit, unde *iam proprio nomine perdito peccatrix consueverat appellari. Sed, cum fChristus gillic et alibi praedicaret, illa hnutu inspirata *divino ad domum Simonis leprosi, iubi *audivit eum discumbere, properavit. Et non audens, ut peccatrix, inter iustos comparere *retro secus pedes domini kmansit, ubi pedes eius lacrimis lavit, capillis tersit et unguento pretioso perunxit.
